name: Bitcoin
description: Cryptocurrency

name: Hydra
description: Large RU-language darknet market

name: The Dark Overlord
description: Ransomware/extortion group

name: Escrow Service
description: Marketplace escrow capability

name: Tails
description: Amnesic live operating system; runs entirely in RAM from read-only media; forces all traffic through Tor via OS-level firewall; overwrites RAM on shutdown. Debian-based.

name: Whonix
description: Two-VM anonymity system: Gateway VM (Tor routing) + Workstation VM (applications). Debian/Kicksecure-based. Protocol-Leak-Protection architecture.

name: Kicksecure
description: Hardened Debian-based OS. AppArmor enforcement; SUID disabler; permission hardener; no open server ports by default. Base OS for Whonix.

name: Qubes-Whonix
description: Whonix Gateway/Workstation running as Qubes AppVMs on Xen hypervisor. Smallest blast radius under browser RCE among surveyed privacy OS stacks.

name: Xen Hypervisor
description: Type-1 bare-metal hypervisor used by Qubes OS. Provides hardware-level VM isolation via separate Xen domains (dom0/domU).

name: Whonix Gateway VM
description: Dedicated VM that routes all Workstation traffic through Tor. Enforces Protocol-Leak-Protection; Workstation has no direct network access.

name: Whonix Workstation VM
description: Application VM in Whonix architecture. No direct network; all traffic routed via Gateway. Tor Browser recommended for protocol-level cleanup.

name: Disposable VM
description: Ephemeral Qubes VM created from template; destroyed after use. Provides session-level isolation and minimal forensic residue within Qubes architecture.

name: Docker
description: Linux container runtime sharing host kernel. Provides process/network/filesystem isolation via namespaces and cgroups.

name: Podman
description: Rootless Linux container runtime. Similar isolation model to Docker but daemonless and supports rootless operation by default.

name: Flatpak
description: Linux application sandboxing framework. Uses namespaces and seccomp for isolation; applications request permissions via portals.

name: Snap
description: Canonical application sandboxing framework for Linux. Uses AppArmor and seccomp for confinement.

name: CVE-2025-2783
description: Critical Chrome sandbox escape vulnerability (2025). Affects Chromium-based browsers including Tor Browser on Windows.

name: CVE-2025-2857
description: Critical Firefox/Tor Browser sandbox escape vulnerability (2025). Enables escape from browser process sandbox on Windows.

name: CVE-2025-9074
description: runc container escape advisory (2025). Demonstrates host compromise from within a Linux container via runtime vulnerability.

name: Browser Process Sandbox
description: Multi-process isolation within browsers (Chrome site isolation / Firefox Fission). Constrains renderer exploits to sandbox scope.

name: VPN-then-Tor Configuration
description: User connects to commercial VPN then uses Tor Browser through the tunnel. ISP sees VPN; VPN provider sees Tor guard IPs; Tor guard sees VPN server IP.

name: Tor-then-VPN Configuration
description: User connects to Tor then VPN inside Tor circuit. ISP sees Tor usage; VPN provider sees destinations but not user real IP; sites see VPN IP not Tor exit.

name: Commercial Tor-Mode VPN
description: VPN products advertising Onion-over-VPN or Tor mode. Architectures vary and are often poorly documented; Tor Project warns against relying on such modes.

name: AS-Level Global Passive Observer
description: Adversary with visibility across multiple autonomous systems. Can observe both sides of Tor circuits for traffic correlation. Beyond single-ISP scope.

name: VPN Kill Switch
description: Mechanism to block all non-VPN traffic if VPN tunnel drops. Prevents real IP exposure during VPN failure. Effectiveness varies by implementation.

name: WTF-PAD (Adaptive Padding)
description: Tor circuit/link padding defense. Framework shipped in Tor but no default state machines enabled. Originally cut classic WF to near-random; later DF achieves ~90% accuracy against it.

name: Walkie-Talkie (Half-Duplex Shaping)
description: Application-layer half-duplex traffic shaping. Research prototype. Constrains DF to ~49.7% closed-world accuracy near theoretical 50% bound but degrades UX.

name: Tamaraw (Fixed-Rate Padding)
description: Fixed-rate direction-specific padding defense. Bandwidth overhead can exceed 100%. Not deployed in Tor core. Strong but prohibitively expensive for large-scale use.

name: DeTorrent (Adversarial Padding)
description: Adversarial padding-only defense via pluggable transport. Reduces WF attacker accuracy by ~61.5% relative to undefended Tor. Leading practical candidate.

name: FRONT (Pluggable Transport Shaping)
description: Traffic shaping via pluggable transports. Moderate effectiveness; primarily useful for censorship-resistance deployments.

name: Tor Connection-Level Padding
description: Deployed in Tor. Adds ~69 KB per one-time connection. Negligible latency. Not WF-specific; reduces resolution of per-flow netflow data.

name: Tor Circuit-Level Padding Machines
description: Deployed for onion services since vanguards. State-machine based. Targeted hardening not comprehensive WF protection.

name: Deep Fingerprinting (DF)
description: CNN-based website fingerprinting attack. ~98% closed-world accuracy on undefended Tor; ~90% against WTF-PAD in curated datasets.

name: Tik-Tok (Timing-Based WF)
description: Timing-aware website fingerprinting attack using directional timing features. ~93.5% accuracy on WTF-PAD traces.

name: DeepCoFFEA (Flow Correlation)
description: Deep-learning flow correlation attack for deanonymising Tor circuits by correlating entry and exit traffic patterns.

name: GTT23 (WF Evaluation Dataset)
description: Realistic WF evaluation dataset using genuine Tor browsing traces. Provides grounded accuracy estimates lower than lab-only closed-world results.

name: WFDefProxy
description: Research tool for implementing and evaluating WF defenses on live Tor. Shows simulated and live defense implementations agree on relative strength rankings.
